moves.1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 d6 3. Bc4 Nf6 4. Ng5: Now black must protect Pf7.  Be6 nets white a pawn, but Qe7 or Qd7 trades bishop and knight for queen, plus wrecks castling.  Good deal for white either way.  Here black should have moved Ph6 or Bf7 instead of the knight to block this.
moves.6. g4 Bg6 7. h4 c5: No, Ph5 takes black's bishop.  Black Ph5 instead protects against NxPf7.
moves.8. h5 Nfd7 9. hxg6 Qxg5: Excellent!  Too early in the morning for annotations.
moves.10. gxf7+ Kd8 11. Rh5 Qf4 12. d3 Qg3+ 13: Oops, Rg8+ allows pawn promotion, and QxRa8 too.
moves.25... Nd4 26. Bb3 c4: Nice move, though white could opt to save the rook.
moves.27. dxc4: Now the rook costs only that pawn.  Two pawns...
moves.27... Nxe6 28. cxb5 axb5: No!  The knight is lost!  So young.
moves.32... Rxe6 33. a4 Be7 34. a5 Bxb4 35. a6: You cannot afford todo that!  White wins a queen.  Or tradesapawnfor a rook.always a good deal.
moves.37. Kg3 Bc3: The bishop was protecting f8.  Threatening the rook does not prevent the pawn rook trade at a8.
I would have taken Rd8+ instead.
moves.42... Be1+ 43. Kh3 Rb8: Rf8 would be slightly better.  You cannot have the king and rook lined up or you lose the rook.  So it or the king had to move.
moves.44. Rd7#: Qd1 nets the bishop.  Oh, never mind.  The king couldn't move anyway.
